I was looking at the Apple HomePod for awhile as an alternative to spending big money on a sound system.  I don't have an iPhone, just an iPad, so I'm not immersed in the Apple environment.  I scooped up the HomePod and Apple TV on a nice sale for what I'd consider a very reasonable price to give this a try with my new LG OLED TV.

Price:
The cost of the HomePod is pretty steep if you don't get it on sale(which aren't ran often).  If you're like me and want a pair of HomePods to substitute for a sound system, then it will run you $600 purchasing at full price.  I do feel that's pretty costly.

Setup:
Very quick and easy to setup with my iPad.  Linking it with Apple TV was even quicker.

Sound quality:
Sound quality to this little speaker is fantastic!  Very clear and crisp audio.  Speakers pushing sound up and to the sides really help in bouncing sound off the walls to give a surround sound vibe to this.  And I only have one.  Bass can get strong, which caught me off guard.  It's great for music!  Good for movies(probably need 2 HomePods to really excel at movies).

Smart speaker:
Siri is just a few words away.  I don't use Siri often, but for quick and easy questions or commands, she gets the job done for me.  I'd say Alexa is a little better in the intelligence department, but Siri is still suitable.

Overall thoughts:
I'm very satisfied with the single HomePod I have.  I will grab a second one in the future on a sale.  Clear and high quality sound quality.  Atmos effects with the upward firing speakers.  Only negative I've come across is the price.

Bonus:
I love movie theater type sound.  Since I have Apple TV hooked up to my LG TV, I'm able to pair the TV audio with a soundbar and the HomePod at the same time.  I do have to manually set the temp audio output for the soundbar each time, but with the sound of the HomePod added to the TV speakers and a Samsung Q990d, the sound it ridiculously amazing in that room!  Low ceilings and not an overly large room helps contain the sound, but the rumble during action scenes is as good or better than at a theater.  Hard to believe as I always had the impression you need to spend big money on a receiver, sub, and speakers for that type of audio quality.  But I'm a very happy camper. Suspecting wifi interference I moved that homepod to another location far away from the wifi and right next to a blinky light display. I recently purchased a pair of HomePods to complement my Apple ecosystem at home. I have to admit, the speakers themselves sounded fantastic... when they actually worked. However, the setup process for these speakers was incredibly frustrating.

Initially, the setup was a breeze. However, things took a turn when I decided to upgrade my Apple TV to support eArc for my TV. After performing a factory reset, the HomePods simply refused to set up like they did the first time. I'm not sure if this was due to a new update to the HomeKit, but I had to make around 20 attempts before they finally progressed past the "Configuring" stage, which took hours. To resolve the issue, I ended up deleting my HomeKit Home and re-pairing everything, and that seemed to solve the problem for a little while, although it felt like an extreme measure to get these speakers to work.

Another issue I encountered was sound cutting out while playing games or watching movies. This was incredibly frustrating, especially considering that the HomePods were positioned right next to the router and Apple TV. I really wished I could plug in an Ethernet cable or something to avoid using wireless.  Siri is not a great voice assistant sadly for these speakers and would recommend sticking with Alexa instead.

Overall, my initial impression of the HomePods was positive, but it quickly turned into disappointment over time. I ultimately decided to return the HomePods and stick with my Alexa system, which has worked for me for years as my smart speaker. Instead, I invested in a Sonos Arc soundbar, which has been fantastic. While the HomePods may work well for certain home setups, they come with their fair share of quirks and issues to deal with. My recommendation would be to explore alternatives before fully investing in these speakers.

My goal with the HomePod2 was to fill a small studio apartment with room filling ambient sound. Unfortunately, the HomePod2 failed in a number of ways. First, the sound of the speaker is too bright for me. Yes, the base is strong and present, but it is too tight and precise for me, also the mids and vocals seem too bright and artificially present. Second, with one HomePod2 the sound has a wide sound stage, but it still feels like a point source. With two HomePods in mono the sound was just too overwhelmingly bright even at low volumes. Something about the way the audio is being processed made listening uncomfortable. Third, when used as a stereo pair, the sound is very impressive and immersive when listening in the sweet spot, but not so great for general walking around. For all that I had heard about the HomePod having immersive room filling sound, I was not impressed. So I returned one and kept the other. I now use the single HomePod2 to augment my existing setup of three other competitive WiFi Airplay speakers. The auto audio adjustment feature of the HomePod2 works well to "fill in" for the lack of mid range vocal brightness of my other 3 speakers and enhances the room filling ambient effect I'm trying to create. AirPlay enables all my speakers to play in synchrony, two operating as a stereo pair, and two working in mono. However AirPlay can be frustrating at times because it is still slow to initiate and glitchy at times. With all the money Apple can apply to product and software development, both AirPlay and the HomePod2 should be better.

I should start with saying I've been an audio enthusiast/nut  for over 50 years. Semi Audiophile in fact. I have numerous upper and  high end sound equipment in many rooms. I have been extremely pleased and amzed with original HomePods since first hearing a friends single play in a remote room.  That lead me to do some research and I got a pair... when they just made stereo possible with an IOS update. As good as a single on its own sounds, I found a Stereo Pair is easily 10x+ better. And since these are a true omnidirectional point source, they project a very Full and open sound stage in stereo with all the music properly placed. My first pair quickly became 6 pair through the house.  They coexist with the assorted  high end stuff all over. The hig end gear now tends to collect dust vs play. HomePod's full sound plus voice or phone control with Apple Music is oh so easy.  Now I play music so much more as I have renewed passion for music thanks  the easy of use. No need to power on multiple devices and search for proper material on shelves or drawers to hear.  Everything can be streamed and via WiFi vs compressed Blue Tooth. That makes a huge deference in sound quality.  Especially with Apples lossless music. All in one higher end sound w/o all the addition gear, cords, software, and real-estate/furniture to place it all required. I just bought 1'st pair of Gen 2's, so now have 7 pair. I've been comparing OE vs Gen 2 as I break them in.  Impressions so far are the differences are not huge. Gen 2 seems a bit more open and clean with a slightly tighter bass (IMHO). I'd say the OE's go just a tad lower, but the bass is not as tight. I was able to get low but measurable output with 20 Frequency generator on OE's ( gen 1). That was amazing for their size and drivers. Gen 2s' did same  at about 30 Hz  which is still very amazing and impressive. Gen ones are still grand & I Iove them. What I found to date with some varied source material -so far is- 60 % of the time I preferred the new Gen 2's, 30% the OE/Gen 1's, and 10% itr was a draw. DO NOT view HomePods as a pricey speaker. Pricey speakers require a lot of pricey gear to make them work. View HomePods as Complete upper end ALL IN ONE sound system package. Nothing but your iPhone and a music script required (which you already have)... preferably Apple Music as it's Lossless and can be voce controlled to the pod vs need an phone. The sequel is always better at least in this case it is! Refined sound in every way. I purchased 2 of these and the sound is the best I’ve heard from any speaker this size ever!!!!

Purchased the stereo pair to replace a soundbar.  Sound is immersive, Dolby Atmos sounds great!  Setup was kinda tricky (surprised being an Apple product) but reason being one HomePod required firmware update to continue setup.  Once setup, HomePod is easy to use, Siri responds quickly, and handoff from Music app is great!

I’d recommend to hold HomePod from the base as the mesh housing feels kinda soft, and may get damaged or dented if trying to carry it from the sides.

these are seamless and easy to configure. They sound processed but otherwise fairly good. I am not that impressed and kind of on the fence.  Unfortunately, two homepods 2 seem very overpriced. Im using thr ability to feed audio to a pair of these through ARC and an Apple TV to serve as my TV speakers. They sound great and look nice next to my TV. The ARC audio ability works well as well and all of my other devices play through them fine. Super happy overall!

Apple ecosystem is wonky. Won’t act as stereo pair with original version that’s an L. I love Apple, but don of a pair or not in my case

I got rid of my sound bar and bought two of these instead and wow, what a great move!  These sound awesome as an audio system for my Apple TV. AMAZING sound looks good as well smart buy and worth it

I set two of these up with a Apple TV. They were very easy to setup, and the would is great.
Love the sound produced by this speaker, looking forward to purchasing a second!

Great little device, but sound wise, not as great as the first gen. So I decided to keep both of them where they sound great together!

I bought 2 of these to use as a pair with my Apple 4k tv.
I tested it out watching Top Gun: Maverick and Pink Floyd: Delicate Sound of Thunder. The surround sound effect was effective and bass is surprisingly good from a pair of small speakers. It did not sound as good as a Sonos arc with subwoofer and surrounds, but great for a small room set up.

I know there's been many glowing reviews of the new HomePod and some not as glowing. 

Here are my thoughts, the sound is great, there' a solid bass sound out of it. The form factor is nice, it's smaller than a device like the Echo Studio. The built in Tenmp/Humidity sensors are a nice addition. It has that solid Apple build look and quality to it.

Now, would I add a second for stereo sound, probably not. For the price of two I'd go for something like the Sonos Arc which I think has better overall quality and sound. The ability to have two HomePods connected to an Apple TV is a great option, but again at that price I think Sonos would be better for a few dollars more. Plus, if you use them for TV sound you're stuck always being in the Apple universe for all your TV watching. The other issue at least for me, Apple doesn't integrate with SiriusXM or Spotify, to start either of those services you'll need to go to your device and can't simply say "Hey Siri play Spotify/Play Yacht Rock on SiriusXM"

If you're in love with Apple, you'll of course love this, if you're familiar with many of the other smart speaker options, I am not sure you'll see that big of a difference for the cost. (now if it dropped by $50 I think it'd be the ideal price point) I would recommend it for those deeply into the Apple Ecosystem/Apple Home setup. If you're not and more in the Nest/Echo ecosystem then you may be disappointed.

I bought 2 of these. Apple added more features too both the mini Home Pod and the Home Pod 2nd Generation. The new 2nd Generation has the spatial audio. ￼They added Alarms and timers to both models. I highly recommend them both. If you want the spatial audio I recommend you get the 2nd Generation.
Didn’t think this speaker would be this great, but it is. Bought it primarily to pair it with my Apple TV & A95K! No regrets!

It’s Ok for a minimalist or someone in a budget. Not impressed with the sound quality, I didn’t feel the atmos or spatial audio. If you have the chance to stretch your wallet get a good soundbar. In the end is and investment, you don’t buy this stuff every year. Returned both units

I recently purchased the Apple HomePod (2nd Generation) Smart Speaker with Siri in Midnight and I am very impressed with it. The sound quality is excellent and it is very easy to use. I currently have five HomePod Minis which have great sound for their size but I needed something larger for my Family Room that has a 20 ft vaulted ceiling that opens to a loft. This fills the bill and then some. I already have a 7.1 home theater in the same room but this fills the gap when I just want music playing throughout the house with all the HomePods.

If you live in an Apple world, you can’t go wrong.
This thing sounds amazing! Well worth the purchase price.

I almost bought an original HomePod on eBay 3 months ago, glad I didn’t!! This new unit really rocks, it is 3-4 times louder with more bass than my HomePod mini stereo pairs. Even though I was having a bit of difficult setting the speaker up (make sure to have the homekit app installed), everything was great afterwards. Speaker sounds amazing and i would definitely try to buy one more another day to try the home speaker system.

This speaker sounds amazing. I want to buy 2 more for the first floor in the house. I don’t care that the sound quality is not overall better than the original 1st generation HomePod. I’ve heard different opinions anyways. The 2nd generation brings some upgrades that may be important to consider when shopping for a good sounding smart speaker. Siri isn’t as smart as I would like her to be, but she is smart enough to be good assistant, unlike Alexa. She is very fast, reliable, and works well with the Apple ecosystem.
Great sound. Easy pair to my apple tv (latest generation). Overall great U.I
Great sound, the hand off is great ! Will be purchasing another one for pairing.
So far its great! Trying to put it through its paces now.

The original HomePod is one of my favorite devices to consume music on so I was excited to see them bring it back. This model sounds just as good as my original but also adds a few features such as the temperature sensor, U1 chip, and a new processor to power advanced computational audio. Everything worked great out of the box and I am so happy with this purchase.
I wasn't expecting the sound quality out of the speaker.

I have the orginal HomePods. I can barely notice any difference in sound quality betweeb the original and this 2nd generation, However, I can notice a diffence in the speed of siri and connection with smart devices. Also I appreciate the detachable power cable because it makes taking the homepod with me easier.                        One important to note is that you cant pair with the original HomePod to create a stereo pair. However, if you airplay from iphone, ipad, or mac you can select any HomePods you wish and play through them all simultaneously.

I’ve had my stereo pair of HomePods for nearly 5 years now and they sound nearly identical to the 2nd Gen HomePods. Siri responsiveness is nearly identical as well. I would only recommend grabbing these new ones if you absolutely *need* the warranty, and want Matter support with HomeKit in the future. If you only plan on using them as apart of your surround sound setup, save yourself $150 and get the original HomePods.

This speaker is superb. I bought two, one alone is great sound, Apple did a great job on filling the room with sound, the bass, its deep and rich, and it doesnt sound muddy, it sounds full and immersive. Now if you pair it with another speaker, wow, its just even better. It really does fill the room with sound, it sounds like you have speakers right behind you and to the left and right of you, but these speakers are best if you are with Apple’s ecosystem, of course. That is an Appple iPhone, iPad, Apple TV, or Mac. Unfortunately it’s not bluetooth compatible, but you can play it via airplay which works like a charm. Watching movies and shows with this is amazing, I own two mini homepods and connect the two pairs together with my new HomePod pair to get a full “surrounding sound”—though its but there in terms of surround sound system, because Apple has not officially built the concept yet with the HomePods and Mini HomePods but Apple does a fine job of having all the HomePod sync together without a lag.

Looks good, sounds good, and easy to use.  No issues with setup or update. Took it out of the box and plugged it in. It paired with my iPhone within a few seconds. Opened the Home app and updated the saodtware to 16.3 with no issues.

I just dont think its worth 3x a home pod mini and if i need to buy 2 at $600 the question then is would it sound as good as a Sonos play 5? I dont think its loud enough by itself. I think Apple really should have done more. I think for it to sound good you would definitely need to buy 2 of these. In a bedroom its decent but in a large living space such as the living room one is simply not enough to fill the space. I have mixed feelings about it. Maybe if i get another one i can update this review.

I’ve got a pair of these, four feet apart (per apple’s recommendation), about five inches from a wall, mounted on shelves that are barely bigger than the HomePod’s base. In that position, they’re able to project a dome of surround sound through my bedroom, which sounds incredibly immersive when you’re in the center of the room. Even outside of the sweet spot, it still sounds delightful. It’s very impressive to hear no noticeable volume dropoff on sounds that move frok the center channel to around the back — something that more expensive setups with rear surround speakers struggle with in between speakers. Plus, audio is beautifully balanced and detailed. Ive always been one to use headphones, because the details you can hear with them is much greater than speakers are usually capable of producing. But the advanced computational audio Apple has is second to none, and manages to draw headphone-level detail out of speakers that effortlessly rivals my $400 set. I’d heard the original HomePod, but never got one because of the price. I’m so glad I could afford them this time, because they’re going to be with me for many years.
I got one but I’m going to purchase a another to pair with my tv!

I bought these as a preorder and well…

Getting them setup in the home app was easy once my phone was updated.  Setting them up as a pair was fairly smooth too.  That’s where the issues begin.

Even though the speakers were setup as a stereo pair, my Apple TV 4K refused to set them as a default audio for the device.  After rebooting the device I was notified that they needed to be updated to 16.3, so why is apple shipping these things with an incompatible OS? 

Even after updating though, I still had to fight with them to be able to use them with my Apple TV.  I even tried resetting the Apple TV, but that didn’t even fix the issue.  

Anyway, after about 2 hours with fighting with them, they finally decided to cooperate and they’re now the default speakers.  

So, how do they sound?  Honestly, they sound fairly similar to the Sonos Arc, but you can at least add a sub to the Sonos.  They’re not as clean as the Bose 900 though.  So, I can’t honestly say who these make sense for.  

At $600 a pair, there’s only $100 that separates this from the Bose 900, and that can be expanded to a much more complete system.  It also sounds better under most situations.  

The speakers do sound nice though and if you were thinking about grabbing an Arc and nothing else, then this is definitely a better value for the money and the sound profile is very similar. 

I have the Bose, so these are likely going back, but I would certainly have kept these if Apple made a wireless sub for them.

I would play them one at a time and switch it to 1 and then 2 and in my opinion, the 1st generation sounds better. The bass on the 1st generation sounds deeper compared to the 2nd generation. But playing them together sounds really good but I would have to turn the volume up or down on one of them because the volume doesn’t match. Overall though I’m happy. Maybe in the next update they can fix that issue of the volume.
Great sound! Great set up process linking up two as sterio pair.

Bought a pair. They both run 16.0. Failed consistently during setup with iPhone that runs 16.3. During pairing, the Homepod is stuck in the 'being configured...' mode in the Home app. 4 hours with Apple tech support, they are clueless.
